sect1.title: The org.storaged.Storaged bus name
sect1.para: The D-Bus name org.storaged.Storaged on the system bus is used by the Storaged Daemon, storaged. If this daemon isn't running, it will be started if D-Bus messages are sent to the name.

sect1.title: The /org/storaged/Storaged object
sect1.para: The process that owns the well-known D-Bus name org.storaged.Storaged on the system bus (typically storaged) exports an object at the well-known path /org/storaged/Storaged. This object implements the org.freedesktop.DBus.ObjectManager interface and should be used by clients to discover other objects.

sect1.title: The /org/storaged/Storaged/Manager object
sect1.para: The object at the path /org/storaged/Storaged/Manager implements the org.storaged.Storaged.Manager D-Bus interface. This object can be used to inspect and manipulate global state.

sect1.title: The /org/storaged/Storaged/block_devices/* objects
sect1.para: Objects with object paths starting with /org/storaged/Storaged/block_devices/ all represent block devices. Such objects implement the org.storaged.Storaged.Block D-Bus interface and may optionally implement other D-Bus interfaces such as org.storaged.Storaged.Filesystem, org.storaged.Storaged.Partition or org.storaged.Storaged.Loop depending on the block device in question.

Note that interfaces may be added and removed at run-time. For example, if a block device is full of zeroes (or, at least, have zeroes in the known metadata areas), it will not intially implement the org.storaged.Storaged.Filesystem interface; however, if a filesystem is later created on the device (using, say, the
mkfs8
command) and the filesystem is recognized by the OS (specifically, recognized by
udev7 and its device probers), the object will gain the interface. If the device is later zeroed or formatted for use as e.g. swap-space, it will lose the org.storaged.Storaged.Filesystem interface.

sect1.title: The /org/storaged/Storaged/drives/* objects
sect1.para: Objects with object paths starting with /org/storaged/Storaged/drives/ all represent disk drives, typically physical disk drives. Such objects implement the org.storaged.Storaged.Drive D-Bus interface and may optionally implement other D-Bus interfaces such as org.storaged.Storaged.Drive.Ata depending on the drive in question.

A drive object should not to be confused with block device objects (which are used for low-level block devices the OS knows about). For example, if /dev/sda and /dev/sdb are block devices for two paths to the same drive, there will be only drive object but two block device objects.

sect1.title: The /org/storaged/Storaged/mdraid/* objects
sect1.para: Objects with object paths starting with /org/storaged/Storaged/mdraid/ represent Linux Software RAID arrays. Such objects implement the org.storaged.Storaged.MDRaid D-Bus interface.
These objects should not to be confused with block device objects (which are used for low-level block devices the OS knows about).

sect1.title: The /org/storaged/Storaged/jobs/* objects
sect1.para: Objects with object paths starting with /org/storaged/Storaged/jobs/ all represent long-running tasks, typically initiated by the user and are guaranteed to implement the org.storaged.Storaged.Job D-Bus interface.

sect1.title: Authorization Checks
sect1.para: Many methods and operations offered by storaged requires the calling user to be sufficiently authorized. Whether the user is authorized is checked using polkit allowing the administrator to configure fine-grained permissions via polkit authorization rules.

There is not necessarily a one-to-one relationship between D-Bus methods and polkit actions - typically the relationship is more complicated and depends on both the context of the process invoking the method, the object the method is acting on and possibly more factors. For example, the Filesystem.Mount() method call may check that the caller is authorized for one of the four actions org.storaged.Storaged.filesystem-mount, org.storaged.Storaged.filesystem-mount-system, org.storaged.Storaged.filesystem-mount-other-seat or org.storaged.Storaged.filesystem-mount-fstab depending on circumstances.

Often there will be two polkit actions for one operation - one for so-called system devices and one for non-system devices. In this context system device refers to the value of the Block:HintSystem D-Bus property and is normally only TRUE for devices not considered removable (devices considered removable include USB attached storage, Flash media and optical drives). See for how to control if a device is considered a system device.

The polkit actions are not considered stable and may change from release to release so administrators should take notice when upgrading from one version of storaged to another. For example, polkit authorization rules may need to be updated to match an updated policy.

See for the variables that can be used to assist in determining if the caller is authorized (note that each variable may not be set for request). For example, a polkit authorization rule for any of the org.storaged.Storaged.filesystem-mount* actions can use the device variable to determine if the caller is authorized to mount a specific block device.

sect1.title: The options parameter
sect1.para: Many method calls take a parameter of type 'a{sv}' that is normally called options. The following table lists well-known options:

auth.no_user_interaction
If set to TRUE, then no user interaction will happen when checking if the method call is authorized.
